citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
In the outdoor flight building, which contained both rehabilitation and exhibit animals, a medication box used primarily for
rehabilitation purposes per the Licensee, but not labelled for this purpose, contained many medications that were either
not adequately labeled and/or were out of date. Medical supplies that are not properly labeled and/or not properly stored,
could deteriorate, become contaminated, or be misused, possibly resulting in harm to the health and well-being of the
animals. Medicines used to prevent or treat disease must be properly stored, labeled, and not expired in order for them to
appropriately and effectively prevent, control, and/or treat diseases.
Correct by: 12/26/2024

In an outdoor enclosure containing a single Turkey Vulture, there were strips of shredded plastic tarp covering the about
1/3 of the cage ground. The Licensee reported that the Turkey Vulture regularly shreds the tarp and the bird remains free
in enclosure at all times. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they protect the birds from
injury.
Correct by: 01/13/2025

In the Eurasian eagle owl enclosure and the Turkey Vulture enclosure each had walls with exposed damaged plywood
and/or particleboard that was not able to be effectively cleaned and sanitized. There was an approximately 3in tall strip of
black slimy material, most consistent with mold, along the bottom of 2 panels of the back wall. The back wall of the Turkey
Vulture was old plywood and leaning into the interior of the enclosure. Primary enclosures must be constructed and
maintained so that all surfaces in contact with the birds may be readily cleaned and/or sanitized in accordance with 3.158
or be replaced when worn or soiled.
Correct by: 01/29/2025

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility did not have a documented environment enhancement plan to promote psychological well-being of their avian
species as required by the Animal Welfare Act. The facility must develop, document and follow a species appropriate plan
for environmental enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by
the attending veterinarian, and at a minimum must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special
considerations, restraint, and exemptions to the plan regulation and be in accordance with currently accepted professional
standards.
Correct by: 01/17/2025

The method of thawing frozen whole prey diets for the raptors is not sufficient to protect the food from potential
contamination. The facility is currently thawing frozen whole prey food items (quail, rodents, chicks) at room temperature
on a kitchen counter. The facility needs to address the manner of thawing and handling whole prey diet items for the
health and welfare of the birds and protected from contamination.
Correct by: 12/26/2024

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
There were 3 wild Turkey Vultures perching on the top of the Turkey Vulture outdoor enclosure and they were passing
droppings and flying over the enclosure, contaminating the food and water. A safe and effective program for the control of
insects, ectoparasites and avian and mammalian pests must be established and maintained so as to promote the health
and well-being of the birds and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas.
Correct by 1/13/2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
In the outdoor flight building, which contained both rehabilitation and exhibit animals, a medication box used primarily for 
rehabilitation purposes per the Licensee, but not labelled for this purpose, contained many medications that were either 
not adequately labeled and/or were out of date. Medical supplies that are not properly labeled and/or not properly stored, 
could deteriorate, become contaminated, or be misused, possibly resulting in harm to the health and well-being of the 
animals. Medicines used to prevent or treat disease must be properly stored, labeled, and not expired in order for them to 
appropriately and effectively prevent, control, and/or treat diseases. 
Correct by: 12/26/2024 
3.153(a)(1)(ii) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
In an outdoor enclosure containing a single Turkey Vulture, there were strips of shredded plastic tarp covering the about 
1/3 of the cage ground. The Licensee reported that the Turkey Vulture regularly shreds the tarp and the bird remains free 
in enclosure at all times. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they protect the birds from 
injury.  
Correct by: 01/13/2025 
3.153(a)(1)(ix) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
In the Eurasian eagle owl enclosure and the Turkey Vulture enclosure each had walls with exposed damaged plywood 
and/or particleboard that was not able to be effectively cleaned and sanitized. There was an approximately 3in tall strip of 
black slimy material, most consistent with mold, along the bottom of 2 panels of the back wall. The back wall of the Turkey 
Vulture was old plywood and leaning into the interior of the enclosure. Primary enclosures must be constructed and 
maintained so that all surfaces in contact with the birds may be readily cleaned and/or sanitized in accordance with 3.158 
or be replaced when worn or soiled. 
Correct by: 01/29/2025 
3.154

Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility did not have a documented environment enhancement plan to promote psychological well-being of their avian 
species as required by the Animal Welfare Act. The facility must develop, document and follow a species appropriate plan 
for environmental enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by 
the attending veterinarian, and at a minimum must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special 
considerations, restraint, and exemptions to the plan regulation and be in accordance with currently accepted professional 
standards. 
Correct by: 01/17/2025 
3.155(a) 
   
Feeding 
The method of thawing frozen whole prey diets for the raptors is not sufficient to protect the food from potential 
contamination. The facility is currently thawing frozen whole prey food items (quail, rodents, chicks) at room temperature 
on a kitchen counter. The facility needs to address the manner of thawing and handling whole prey diet items for the 
health and welfare of the birds and protected from contamination. 
Correct by: 12/26/2024 
3.158(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
There were 3 wild Turkey Vultures perching on the top of the Turkey Vulture outdoor enclosure and they were passing 
droppings and flying over the enclosure, contaminating the food and water. A safe and effective program for the control of 
insects, ectoparasites and avian and mammalian pests must be established and maintained so as to promote the health 
and well-being of the birds and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. 
Correct by 1/13/2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representative.
